segments.text: Lunch break. Back at camp after a great morning hike. Made it up to 2100 meters - legs are feeling it.
Let me eat and then plan this afternoon's route. I've got the map out... okay, so I'm here at base camp.
If I head northwest from here, there's a ridge trail that goes up to 2400 meters. That's my afternoon goal.
The guidebook says it's about 3 hours round trip. Should get me back before dark, which is around 5:30 PM this time of year.
Snow conditions look good from what I could see this morning. No avalanche risk at these elevations right now.
I'll pack the emergency bivvy just in case. And extra layers - temperature drops fast up there.
Water - I'll take two liters. Snacks: energy bars, nuts, some chocolate. Chocolate tastes amazing at altitude.
Navigation: GPS, compass, paper map. I know it's overkill but redundancy keeps you alive in the mountains.
First aid kit stays in my pack at all times. Along with the satellite communicator in case something goes wrong.
Okay, let me finish this dehydrated meal. Chicken and rice - surprisingly good for camp food.
You know what's nice about solo hiking? I can move at exactly my own pace. No pressure to keep up or slow down.
And if I want to just sit and stare at a view for 20 minutes, I can. No one's waiting for me.
Alright, food's done. Let me clean up and get moving. I want to be on the ridge by 1:30.

environment.background_sounds: wind, birds, water boiling on stove, paper map rustling
